events.text: Like I said, last night had been rough.
I showed up to the Thoroughbred Estate just after dark. Yung Dab was a tough man to get ahold of at the best of times, but one of his cronies said HE wanted to meet ME. Wanted MY services.
Thought he could buy me.

I knew better than to think I couldn't be bought. Las Borpas taught me that everybody had a price, a string you could pull. Sometimes the string wasn't on the wallet. Sometimes it was on your heart. But everybody had one.
Maybe I'd do him a favor, make him a little money, or get one claw up on the other rats racing around Las Borpas in the dark and mud. But I'd make sure whatever I got in return would bring him down.
He let me in himself. Like I said, the man could reclusive. Kept a few bodies around the house to do work.
The cook (Henry, I now knew) was talking to himself in the kitchen. Thoroughbred called for a drink, and Henry shouted that he was busy.
Pussa bitch.
Is that any way to talk to the people that prop you up, Thoroughbred?
I couldn't wait to sink him.
We went up to his office to talk business, and it was the first time I'd spoken directly to him in person.
Not sure I was surprised when he started throwing insults my way. Childish, gleeful, like all he really wanted to do was waste my goddamn time.
Little bitch.
Pussa bitch.
Suck my diiiiiiiick, dawg.
And the whole time, giggling to himself like the village idiot.
He thought he was immune, hiding behind money, behind threats, behind a cohort of croneys that would close rank at his beck and call.
Everybody's afraid of you, Thoroughbred. Friends and enemies.
But not me.

I stood up. Can't remember what I said to him. He threw a few paper thin insults my way as I stepped towards him, rage welling up inside me like some magnificent demon, promising me retribution at the cost of justice.
This one was for Las Borpas.
I reached down towards his desk, my hand closing around something thin and metal, but sturdy. A tray.

I swung, connected with his temple. The tittering madman, shocked into silence, tried to stand, but he was staggered, bleeding, stumbling. I swung again on crown of his head, bringing down on Thoroughbred the weight of a city he'd tried to put under his heel.
After a few more swings I realized what I'd done, and that he wasn't moving.
It was a blur after that. For all the criminals I'd caught, and for all the legal corners I'd cut, I didn't know a damn thing about getting away with murder.

I stashed the weapon, but I couldn't remember where. I would have sneaked out the front door, left it unlocked, but I saw the light from the kitchen and heard Henry, still talking to the camera. I needed another way out.
I looked around, and saw the grounds. Once I was outside I bolted, wind and blood roaring in my ears. I vaulted the barred fence but felt it catch my coat, stripping a scrap of it away.

I'd murdered Maximilian Thoroughbred, and then I ran, deep into the misty night of Las Borpas. When I finally found myself at home, who knows what time, I hit the bottle, hard, to send myself to sleep.
Then I awoke to a phone call.
